entry.title: Planning guidance: letters to chief planning officers
entry.summary: Guidance on various aspects of the planning system, given in letters to chief planning officers of local planning authorities.
entry.content:
Introduction

The Department for Communities and Local Government regularly writes to chief planning officers of local planning authorities in England, providing guidance about various aspects of the planning system.

These letters are available to download below, grouped by year of publication.

Letter about recent planning activities and changes to the Local Plan Regulation 2012 (28 December 2012)

PDF, 83 KB, 3 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Letter about recent planning activities and changes to the Local Plan Regulation 2012 (28 December 2012)").

entry.title: ERDF regional guidance: East Midlands
entry.summary: The East Midlands is one of 9 English regions to qualify for Competitiveness and Employment funding.
entry.content:
Introduction

Under the 2007 to 2013 programme, the region can receive 268.5million of European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) investment.

Priorities

The East Midlands Operational Programme document outlines the investment priorities for the region. It focuses on 2 main priorities:

Priority 1: increasing productivity through innovation and sustainable business practice

This priority will focus on increasing commercialisation of innovation of small and medium-sized enterprises in the regions priority sectors: transport equipment, construction, food and drink, health and in businesses with high growth potential to create higher value added products and services. It will include support for small and medium-sized enterprise engagement in research and development for emerging technologies and for innovation to improve resource efficiency.

Priority 2: increasing sustainable economic and enterprise activity in disadvantaged communities

This priority will focus on stimulating economic and enterprise activity in the most disadvantaged areas whilst exploiting the potential linkages to adjacent areas of economic growth, through a range of actions but with a strong focus on enterprise and start-up activity. It will also aim to create new economic opportunities by building local capacity, resources and support; reviving local infrastructure and environments and stimulating and supporting enterprise.

Key programme documents

The following documents for the East Midlands ERDF competitiveness programme can be downloaded at the bottom of this page.

East Midlands Operational Programme

The 2007-2013 East Midlands ERDF Competitiveness Operational Programme, sets out the regions strategy and priorities for delivering ERDF funds for the period from 2007 to 2013. The Operational Programme has been approved by the European Commission (EC).

East Midlands 2007 to 2013 ERDF competitivesness operational programme

PDF, 625 KB, 112 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("East Midlands 2007 to 2013 ERDF competitivesness operational programme").

2010 interim programme assessment

The Programmes 2010 interim assessment report is now available. The aim of this exercise was to assess whether the focus of the Programme continued to be relevant; whether the delivery arrangements in place (relating to governance and sub-regional) were still the most appropriate; and if there were any emerging lessons to learn/areas of best practice to consider for future delivery.

Interim programme assessment

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Interim programme assessment").

Publicity and communications strategy

It is an EU regulatory requirement that each ERDF programme has a publicity and communications strategy. This document sets out the proposed publicity and communications activity for the 2007 to 2013 ERDF Competitiveness Programme in the East Midlands, and has been approved by the Local Management Committee (LMC).

Publicity and communications strategy

PDF, 234 KB, 18 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Publicity and communications strategy").

Technical assistance strategy

Technical assistance accounts for 4% of the programmes financial allocation. This strategy outlines how this funding will be spent and managed throughout the lifetime of the programme. The strategy has been approved by the Programme Monitoring Committee.

ERDF investment framework

PDF, 256 KB, 50 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("ERDF investment framework").

For more information contact the ERDF Programme Delivery Team: East Midlands on 0303 444 6427 or email em.erdfenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Local ERDF guidance

From the 1 April 2012, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) adopted a standardised approach to the management and delivery of the ERDF Programmes across England. This includes the introduction of a new suite of documentation - including forms and guidance - which projects approved to receive funding after 1 April 2012 will need to use and follow.

For projects required to use the new documentation, visit the National Guidance section.

All forms and guidance in existence prior to the 1 April 2012 that ERDF supported projects have used or are currently using, are available from your local Programme Delivery Team. To access this and for more information contact the Programme Delivery Team: East Midlands on 0303 444 6427 or email em.erdfenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Please ensure that you are using the correct forms and guidance for your project. If you have any questions regarding this seek clarity from your local Programme Delivery Team through the details shown above.

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Contact list").

Local management committee

A series of changes introduced by the Government have had an impact on the way in which the East Midlands ERDF programme is both governed and delivered. From 1 July 2011, responsibility for delivering the ERDF Programme in the East Midlands transferred from the East Midlands Development Agency (emda) to DCLG.

The Government is committed to a programme of localism, shifting power away from the centre and enabling local partners to drive change in tune with their own priorities. DCLG has confirmed therefore that, following consultation with Programme partners, the Programme Monitoring Committee (PMC) which has previously overseen the ERDF Programme in each region, will be replaced by new LMCs.

The 16 June 2011 meeting was the last formal meeting of the 2007-13 ERDF Programme Monitoring Committee. A LMC has now been established with new terms of reference. Mark Carroll, Director of Decentralisation and the Big Society at DCLG has been appointed as the East Midlands LMC Chair with Rachel Quinn, Chief Executive Officer of One East Midlands as Deputy Chair.

Responsibilities of the LMC

In developing LMCs, the ECs partnership requirements (Article 11 Council Regulation (EC) 1083/2006 - Annex C) will be honoured, as will the requirement on Member States to establish partnership committees (Article 63 - Annex C).

The LMC will be responsible for the strategic leadership of the 2007-13 East Midlands ERDF Competitiveness Programme. As set out in Article 65, the responsibilities of the LMC will include:

  • consideration and approval of project selection criteria
  • reviewing progress towards the achievement of programme targets and Priority Axes objectives through receiving and considering
  • performance implementation data
  • receiving and considering consistent, up-to-date management information for the programme, as required by the Managing Authority
  • consideration and approval of annual and final reports
  • consideration and approval of programme evaluations and resulting Operational Programme amendments; and
  • strategic linkages with other structural funds, domestic programmes and wider UK economic policy

entry.title: ERDF regional guidance: North East
entry.summary: Guidance about the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the North East of England and how to apply for funding.
entry.content:
Introduction

The ERDF is a funding stream which is allocated to regions by the European Union to stimulate regional economies.

The North East of England is one of 9 regions to qualify for Competitiveness and Employment funding.

Under the 2007 to 2013 programme, the region can receive 375.7 million of ERDF investment.

Calls for proposals

The latest calls for proposals will be open between 7 January 2013 and 1 March 2013. These are:

  • a call for both capital and revenue based activity under Priority 1 of the operational programme: enhancing and exploiting innovation
  • a call for both capital and revenue based activity under Priority 2 of the operational programme: business growth and enterprise

Full details can be found in the applying for funding section.

This is likely to be the final opportunity to make applications to the ERDF Programme.

Priorities

The North East operational programme document (see Programme documents below) outlines the investment priorities for the region. It focuses on 2 main priorities:

Priority 1: enhancing and exploiting innovation

By 2015 the operational programme aims to enhance the exploitation of science, technology and other innovation leading to the creation of new small and medium enterprises, the creation or safeguarding of gross jobs, a percentage of which will be in disadvantaged areas and the generation of net Gross Value Added. There will be a strong emphasis on energy and environmental technology.

Priority 2: business growth and enterprise

By 2015 the operational programme aims to contribute to increased business density and higher levels of productivity and competitiveness with the business base leading to the creation of new small and medium-sized enterprises, the creation and safeguarding of gross jobs, improved environmental management and energy efficiency in assisted small and medium-sized enterprises and the generation of net Gross Value Added.

Programme documents

This section provides key documents which detail the programme and how it is managed. They also provide important information that will help potential applicants work out whether projects are eligible for ERDF support. They will also be of interest to people wishing to find out more about the programme for research purposes.

Potential applicants are also advised to:

  • carefully consider the information within the relevant commissioning documents and associated guidance within the guide on applying for ERDF funding
  • consider national ERDF documents available in ERDF: national guidance

Operational programme

Below is the original North East England Regional Competitiveness and Employment ERDF operational programme 2007 to 2013 document. It was prepared for Government Office for the North East and One North East with input from a project board comprising representatives from a broad range of sectors. The operational programme sets out the rationale for the programme, the strategic approach and management arrangements.

ERDF North East operational programme 2007 to 2013 (original)

PDF, 2.18 MB, 181 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("ERDF North East operational programme 2007 to 2013 (original)").

In July 2011 the North East England ERDF Competitiveness Programmes local management committee agreed to submit a modification to the North East ERDF operational programme to the European Commission. The modification:

  • reflects changes in the socio-economic conditions in the North East and the impact of changes in government policy
  • takes account of the findings of the programmes mid-term evaluation
  • proposed a reduction in some non financial targets and increases in others to reflect changing conditions
  • broadened the scope of activity to give greater emphasis to capital investment

The European Commission approved the modified operational orogramme on the 15 of February 2012. The modified operational porogramme is accompanied by a revised Strategic Environmental Assessment.

The North East England ERDF operational programme investment framework sets out the arrangements and processes which will be used to translate the ERDF vision, objectives and strategic priorities set out in the 2007 to 2013 operational programme into practical, deliverable programmes of activity and projects during the period October 2011 to December 2013. It sets out the key high level and operating principles which underpin the programmes approach to commissioning project activity and managing project applications.

This schedule allocates functions relating to the management and implementation of the operational programme.

The ERDF programme has been subject to an independent mid-term evaluation undertaken by Regeneris Consulting.

Findings include:

  • pre-2010 programme broadly on track to deliver against targets
  • the programme is well designed, well managed and responsive

Local ERDF guidance

From 1 April 2012, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) adopted a standardised approach to the management and delivery of the ERDF programmes across England. This includes the introduction of a new suite of documentation - including forms and guidance - which projects approved to receive funding after 1 April 2012 will need to use and follow.

For projects required to use the new documentation see the guide on ERDF: national guidance.

All forms and guidance in existence before 1 April 2012 that ERDF-supported projects have used or are currently using are available from your local programme delivery team.

Please ensure that you are using the correct forms and guidance for your project. If you have any questions, please contact the North East Programme Delivery Team on 0303 444 6475 or NE.ERDFenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Details of the outputs that projects supported by the North East ERDF programme are required to deliver are set out in the document below.

Outputs guidance

PDF, 445 KB, 42 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Outputs guidance").

Local management committee

The North East England local management committee engages key North East partners in overseeing the strategic delivery of the programme. It performs tasks and responsibilities laid down by the European Commission to satisfy itself of the quality and effectiveness of the programmes implementation.

The local management committee is responsible for the programmes strategic direction and formal monitoring, ensuring that targets are met and redirecting work as and when required. The committee is not an executive body and therefore does not award grants.

Membership of the committee is governed by EU Commission regulations and is made up by representation from sectors across the North East. Please see below for a list of members.

Before 1 July 2011, governance of the programme was through the programme monitoring committee. Minutes from programme monitoring committee meetings together with the latest minutes from local management committee meetings are available to download once they are formally agreed and are accessible below.

The programme executive group is a sub-group of the local management committee which supports the local ERDF team in the delivery and management of the programme. Terms of reference are available below.

Latest news

ERDF annual stakeholder event 2012

The North East ERDF annual stakeholder event 2012 was successfully held on 17 October at Durham County Hall. A 50-strong audience heard Lesley Calder, Head of Programme Delivery Team, talk about the success and achievements of the programme to date including helping nearly 90,000 new and existing small and medium enterprises to develop and grow their business and creating over 7,000 new jobs, contributing to local growth across the North East.

Attendees heard a presentation by Mark Elliott, the Chief Executive Officer of DigitalCity, who talked about growing his project in Middlesbrough with the help of ERDF to create a vibrant, successful and self-sustaining supercluster in the ICT sector which has to date created 474 jobs with a long-term aim of creating 3,000 by 2022. Mark spoke about DigitalCitys potential to be a world leader in its field, using a radical approach to grow an initial concept developed 9 years ago into a super-cluster creating jobs, businesses and wealth in the North East.

Stakeholders heard how the concept has grown through a successful partnership with a range of local partners and is providing support to digital entrepreneurs at all stages of their enterprise journey. DigitalCity Innovation harnesses the enterprise potential of Teesside University students to create their own businesses and also uses their expertise to support local growth through knowledge transfer projects, placements and fellowships with local businesses. New businesses are supported by DigitalCity Business based at the flagship development Boho One, part of the exciting Boho Zone, the digital and creative hub dedicated to offering world-class support to businesses across the North East, helping create 148 businesses so far.

The second half of the annual stakeholder event was focussed on ERDF post-2014 with Iain Derrick, European Strategy and ERDF Secretariat Manager providing an introduction and summary followed by Kevin Richardson from the Department for Business, Innovation and Strategy facilitating table discussions on what stakeholders want to see in the next round of ERDF programmes in 2014 to 2020.

Partners discussed a broad range of issues and identified the following as key considerations in the development of the next round of structural funds programmes in the North East:

  • maintaining strong local control over decision making
  • programme design and funding allocations should reflect local priorities in a bottom up approach to supporting local growth
  • clarity required on programme geographies as soon as possible
  • programme geographies should take account of local enterprise partnership areas as functional economic areas
  • allocations ring fenced for local areas
  • evidence of market failure, research data and evaluation of current investments is vital to underpin evidenced based policy decisions.
  • need to build on the success of current investments eg Innovation Connectors
  • integration of ERDF and European Social Fund would improve local control and facilitate coordinated local actions.
  • maintain locally managed business growth funds such as JEREMIE

ERDF practitioner network

Across North East England there is a network of people supporting the development and delivery of ERDF projects. The local ERDF team supports an ERDF practitioner network to create a supportive environment for all ERDF practitioners, develop a strong, well informed ERDF delivery network, and develop a consistent and sound understanding of ERDF requirements. The team also provides ERDF practitioners with access to:

  • a programme of training and information events related to ERDF
  • bulletins and latest news on ERDF technical guidance

If you are involved in any of the following areas, then this network can provide you with support:

  • project development
  • management of ERDF projects
  • compilation and submission of claims
  • management of ERDF finance

If you would like to join the ERDF practitioner network please email your details to: NE.ERDFenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk with the message title Practitioner Network registration.

A number of practitioner network bulletins have been produced. To obtain these please contact the programme team.

E-bulletins

The local ERDF team produces a regular e-bulletin to keep stakeholders up to date with key decisions, major funding approvals and details of programme performance. To register for the bulletin please email your details to NE.ERDFenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk with the message title e-bulletin registration or see below to access previous bulletins.

This contains:

  • ERDF programme performance update
  • outcome of calls for projects
  • ERDF Annual Stakeholder Event 2012
  • ERDF claims
  • ecoConnect
  • keeping in contact

entry.title: National taskforce to end the problem of 'beds in sheds'
entry.content:
A new national taskforcehas been set up to tackle the issue of beds in sheds by taking action against criminal landlords and removing illegal immigrants.

TodayHousing Minister Grant Shapps and Immigration Minister Damian Greenheld the first in a series of cross-Whitehall summits with representatives from the police, the UK Border Agency and local government.

The meetings will find ways to close down thousands of sheds and outbuildings being rented out illegally to migrants, including some with no right to be in the UK.

These tenants are being exploited by ruthless landlords who charge them extortionate rents to live in cramped conditions.

These modern day shanty towns, often visible on websites such as Google Earth, can be plagued with rats and cockroaches- and are potential death traps with dodgy wiring and poor sanitation.

Some foreign tenants wish to return home but, after destroying their passports to avoid removal, find it difficult to do so quickly.

Today, Mr Shapps and Mr Greendiscussed:

  • encouraging councils to make greater use of legal powers across planning, fire safety, housing and environmental health
  • how to better measure the extent and nature of the problem, drawing on information collected by Whitehall and Town Halls
  • how best to ensure councils and the police share the intelligence available and enforcement activity
  • closer working with organisations such as the Indian High Commission to help those wanting to return home;and
  • steps to prevent more beds in sheds from being created.

Housing Minister Grant Shapps said:

It is a scandal that these back garden slums exist to exploit people, many of whom are prepared to return voluntarily to their home country but instead find themselves trapped into paying extortionate rents to live in these cramped conditions.

I want to see a crackdown on these criminal landlords. So today we are launching a national taskforce, made up of the police, local councils, the UK Border Agency and HM Revenue and Customs to close down these beds in sheds, help those living there to be reunited with their families and ensure their so-called landlords feel the full force of the law.

Immigration Minister Damian Green said:

Those with no right to be in the UK must leave the country. If they volunteer to leave, we will help. If they refuse, we will enforce their removal.

The UK Border Agency will do whatever is necessary, working with local authorities and the police, to clear up this problem and enforce our laws against those who are in the UK illegally and the employers who exploit them.

This work is well under way - many individuals have already been removed from the UK and further enforcement visits will follow.

Notes to editors

  1. Some councils have argued that they need to have a new legal power of entry into premises without notice. However, councils already have this ability provided they obtain a magistrates warrant- which provides a proportionate check and balance on the use of such powers.

Twitter

Keep up to date withthe Department by following us on Twitter (external link).

Media enquiries

Visit our newsroom contacts page for media enquiry contact details.

entry.title: ERDF regional guidance: West Midlands
entry.summary: Guidance about the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the West Midlands and how to apply for funding.
entry.content:
Introduction

The European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) is a funding stream which is allocated to regions by the European Union to stimulate regional economies.

The West Midlands is one of 9 regions to qualify for Competitiveness and Employment funding.

Under the 2007 to 2013 programme, the region can receive 400 million of investment.

Priorities

The West Midlands operational programme document (see Programme documents below) outlines the investment priorities for the region. It focuses on 4 main priorities:

Priority 1: promoting innovation and research and development

Aims to improve the regions capacity to translate innovation into commercial outcomes that result in a step change in business productivity and performance. A particular focus is on the regions high class science base, notably its universities and research institutions.

Priority 2: stimulating enterprise development

Aims to increase enterprise in the West Midlands in order to improve regional economic performance. This is being achieved through the provision of tailored business support together with a limited range of integrated access to finance measures.

Priority 3: achieving sustainable urban development

Aims to address the significant concentrations of economic need in certain areas of the region and seeks to generate major employment opportunities accessible to those communities.

Priority 4: developing inter-regional activity

Aims to support the 3 main priorities in tackling problems that are applicable to the region and to maximise learning from current and future inter-regional activity by developing mutually beneficial relationships with partners in the EU via:

  • study visits
  • work shadowing
  • exchange of professional expertise
  • workshops
  • case studies
  • conferences

In addition a fifth priority, technical assistance provides a resource which supports and contributes towards delivering the overall regional strategy by assisting the necessary activities associated with programme management. This includes programme preparation, implementation, monitoring, evaluation and publicity.

Programme documents

Operational programme

A full explanation of the operational programme including all aspects, from the activities to support to the management arrangements, are explained in the operational programming document.

This comprehensive document was originally drawn up by a regional partnership including Advantage West Midlands (the former management organisation of the programme) and other key regional stakeholders in accordance with European and national guidelines. It contains the strategy and evidence base behind the programme. This was updated in March 2012 following the mid-term evaluation.

ERDF West Midlands operational programme: regional competitiveness and employment objective 2007 to 2013 (updated March 2012)

ERDF projects

Business support guide

The West Midlands ERDF Programme provides funding to a range of initiatives and projects that stimulate local growth and regeneration, create jobs and support local businesses.

To help local businesses, ERDF funding is awarded to business support providers, who can directly help individual businesses. To capture details of all the current business support initiatives and provide guidance on where individual businesses can go for more information, a West Midlands ERDF Business Support Guide has been developed.

Version 2 of the guide is available to download in full below, however you can also access and use a searchable database to find the information directly relevant to each business. The database allows various searches including type of support available, eligibility criteria and geographic location within the West Midlands.

The guide will be updated regularly to ensure the latest information is available to businesses in the West Midlands.

Local guidance

From 1 April 2012, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) adopted a standardised approach to the management and delivery of the ERDF programmes across England. This includes the introduction of a new suite of documentation - including forms and guidance - which projects approved to receive funding after 1 April 2012 will need to use and follow.

For projects required to use the new documentation see the guide on ERDF: national guidance.

All forms and guidance in existence before 1 April 2012 that ERDF-supported projects have used or are currently using are available from your local programme delivery team.

Please ensure that you are using the correct forms and guidance for your project. If you have any questions, please contact the West Midlands Programme Delivery Team on 0303 444 6589 or WM.ERDFenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Details of the outputs that projects supported by the West Midlands ERDF programme are required to deliver are set out in the document below.

ERDF West Midlands: output definitions

PDF, 421 KB, 74 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("ERDF West Midlands: output definitions").

Local management committee

Partnership plays a key role in the delivery and management of the ERDF programme. To reflect this, 2 groups have been established, each with a specific role.

The ERDF programme for the West Midlands is overseen by a local management committee (formerly called the programme monitoring committee). This is composed of senior representatives of the bodies of the regional partnership with the membership reflecting the sectoral and sub-regional interests in the programme.

To assist the committee in effectively carrying out its full range of strategic and regulatory functions, it is supported by a sub-committee.

The committee is responsible for ensuring the programmes overall strategic direction, driving it forward so that it meets agreed targets and redirecting the work of the programme as and when necessary over its lifetime. Its key focus is on setting programme direction and strategic review.

Local management sub-committee

The aim of the sub-committee is to support the local management committee in carrying out its responsibilities. Specifically, the principal role and function of the group is to agree and commission, in partnership, the necessary activity to ensure that the different priority areas of the programme may be fulfilled and activity delivered.

The sub-committee, chaired by the deputy chair of the local management committee, will input into the investment frameworks which helps them deliver each priority and meet its objectives, stating the route for project development, implementation details and the timing and sequence of events.

The group is also tasked with raising awareness of the ERDF programme and European funding opportunities and encouraging partners in the sub-regions to apply for ERDF where this is a strategic need.

entry.title: Affordable housing starts and completions funded by the HCA and the GLA: April to September 2012
entry.summary: Latest statistics on affordable housing starts and completions funded by the Homes and Communities Agency and the Greater London Authority.
entry.content:
The latest statistics on affordable housing starts and completions funded by the Homes and Communities Agency (HCA) and the Greater London Authority (GLA) were released on Friday 16 November 2012.

The figures show the supply of homes delivered under the accelerated land disposal programme, the 2011 to 2015 affordable homes programme (including the affordable homes programme, empty homes, homelessness change, mortgage rescue and traveller pitch funding), the economic assets programme, FirstBuy, the Get Britain Building programme, the kickstart housing delivery programme, the national affordable housing programme and the property and regeneration programme. Details about these programmes can be found in the HCA housing statistics release.

The key points were:

  • between 1 April and 30 September 2012, there were 3,735 affordable housing starts on site delivered in England through programmes managed by the HCA and the GLA; this represents an increase of 678% compared to the 480 (revised) started in the same period of the previous year
  • between 1 April and 30 September 2012, there were 11,432 affordable housing completions delivered through programmes managed by the HCA and the GLA; this represents a decrease of 11% compared to the 12,778 completed in the same period in the previous year

Background

Information on the number of affordable homes delivered under the HCA affordable housing programmes is published twice a year. From April 2012, the Mayor of London has had strategic oversight of housing, regeneration and economic development in London. This means that the HCA no longer publish affordable housing starts and completions for London and this responsibility has been taken over by the GLA.

The Department for Communities and Local Government combines data from the HCA and the GLA to publish 6 monthly affordable housing starts and completions delivered nationally under the affordable housing programmes of the HCA and GLA.

More information about the HCA affordable housing statistics.

More information about the GLA affordable housing statistics.

entry.title: DCLG draft statistics plan for 2011 to 2012
entry.summary: Consultation on the Department for Communities and Local Government's proposals for collecting and publishing official statistics in 2011 to 2012.
entry.content:
The draft statistics plan describes the Department for Communities and Local Governments proposals for collecting and publishing official statistics over the period April 2011 to March 2012.

We are seeking:

  • users reactions to our proposals and their views on whether our planned deployment of resources will meet their needs
  • suggestions for the development of any new statistics, products or services
  • suggestions for any further reductions in the amount of data we collect and publish (beyond those already submitted in the context of the single data list)
  • information from users about the particular uses to which they put our statistics

entry.title: ERDF regional guidance: East of England
entry.summary: Guidance about the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the East of England and how to apply for funding.
entry.content:
Introduction

The ERDF is a funding stream which is allocated to regions by the European Union to stimulate regional economies.

East of England is one of 9 regions to qualify for Competitiveness and Employment funding.

Under the 2007 to 2013 programme, the region can receive 110.9 million of ERDF investment.

Priorities

The East of England operational programme document (see Programme documents below) outlines the investment priorities for the region. It focuses on 3 main priorities:

Priority 1

Promoting innovation and knowledge transfer to improve productivity, to encourage commercialisation across the regions research and development base, and establish energy efficient and clean technologies. In turn, this will enable increases in productivity and resource use efficiency, the wider application and take up of information communication technology and other technologies which support innovation and productivity improvements and encourage businesses to engage with Higher Education Institutions and other organisations to effect knowledge transfer.

Priority 2

Stimulating enterprise and supporting successful businesses by overcoming barriers to business creation and expansion, improving access to finance for business and supporting the development of social enterprises (particularly those engaged in low carbon activities), supporting the development of high growth and high value-added businesses, and developing clean technologies and renewable energy clusters.

Priority 3

Ensuring sustainable development, production and consumption by working with communities (both urban and rural) to support local jobs and business growth. To do this in a manner that generates low carbon outcomes, supports the development of low carbon approaches to construction and refurbishment of properties and promotes the efficient use of resources and the minimisation of waste in the region.

Summary of priority axes

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

Local ERDF guidance

From 1 April 2012, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) adopted a standardised approach to the management and delivery of the ERDF programmes across England. This includes the introduction of a new suite of documentation - including forms and guidance - which projects approved to receive funding after 1 April 2012 will need to use and follow.

For projects required to use the new documentation see the guide on ERDF: national guidance.

All forms and guidance in existence before 1 April 2012 that ERDF-supported projects have used or are currently using are available from your local programme delivery team.

Please ensure that you are using the correct forms and guidance for your project. If you have any questions, please contact the East of England Programme Delivery Team on 0303 444 6400 or ee.enquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Details of the outputs that projects supported by the East of England ERDF programme are required to deliver are set out in the document below.

Guidance on programme indicators

PDF, 199 KB, 21 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("Guidance on programme indicators").

Local management committee

The local management committee now replaces the European programme strategy group. The local management committee is the programme monitoring committee for the regional ERDF Competitiveness Programme which is responsible for the strategic leadership of the 2007 to 2013 East of England programme.

The local management committee has been established in accordance with Article 63 of Council Regulation (EC) No. 1083/2006. It will discharge the tasks and responsibilities laid down in Article 65 including:

  • consideration and approval of project selection criteria
  • reviewing progress towards the achievement of programme targets and Priority Axes objectives through receiving and considering performance implementation data
  • receiving and considering consistent, up-to-date management information for the programme, as required by the managing authority
  • consideration and approval of annual and final reports
  • consideration and approval of programme evaluations and resulting operational programme amendments
  • strategic linkages with other structural funds, domestic programmes and wider UK economic policy

Local management committee terms of reference

Local management committee equality and diversity objectives

The East of England local management committee has adopted the following strategic equality and diversity objectives from January 2012:

  1. leadership and strategy: demonstrable commitment
  2. policies, procedures, processes: equalities inputs and outputs main-streamed
  3. partnerships and resources: actions to take account of diverse needs of stakeholders/beneficiaries
  4. projects and programme results: systematic information collected

These objectives will be reviewed annually.

  • the Competitiveness Delivery Group which performs at an operational level and considers expressions of interest and business case applications for projects seeking ERDF funding
  • the Environmental Sustainability Group which provides advice and expertise to the local management committee on best practice in the delivery of environmental sustainability
  • the Equality and Diversity Group which provides advice and expertise to the local management committee on best practice in the delivery of equality and diversity.

entry.title: ERDF regional guidance: North West
entry.summary: Guidance about the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the North West of England and how to apply for funding.
entry.content:
Introduction

The ERDF is a funding stream which is allocated to regions by the European Union to stimulate regional economies.

The North West of England is one of 9 regions to qualify for Competitiveness and Employment funding.

Under the 2007 to 2013 programme, the region can receive 755.5 million of ERDF investment.

Calls for projects

There are currently no live calls for projects within the North West ERDF programme. More calls will be added to this site in the coming weeks so please continue to check these pages.

Priorities

The North West operational programme document (see Programme documents below) outlines the investment priorities for the region. It focuses on 4 main priorities:

Priority 1

Stimulating enterprise and supporting growth in target and markets, such as developing high-value new enterprise, developing higher added value activity in target regional sectors, increasing sustainable consumption and production.

Priority 2

Exploiting innovation and knowledge, such as exploiting the science and research and development base of the region, encouraging innovation to improve productivity in all companies and developing better management and leadership.

Priority 3

Creating the conditions for sustainable growth, such as exploiting the economic potential of major gateways in Merseyside, developing high quality sites and premises of regional importance and supporting the improvement of the regions visitor offer and image.

Priority 4

Growing and accessing employment, such as stimulating enterprise in disadvantaged communities and under-represented groups, supporting linkages to key employment areas and supporting employment creation for areas of regeneration need.

Programme documents

The documents below will help potential applicants to decide if their project is eligible for ERDF support. They will also be of interest to people wishing to find out more general information about the programme.

Operational programme

The full North West operational programme document and a summary version setting out the strategy of the programme are available to download below.

ERDF North West: operational programme

PDF, 2.12 MB, 213 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

Local ERDF guidance

From 1 April 2012, the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG) adopted a standardised approach to the management and delivery of the ERDF programmes across England. This includes the introduction of a new suite of documentation - including forms and guidance - which projects approved to receive funding after 1 April 2012 will need to use and follow.

For projects required to use the new documentation see the guide on ERDF: national guidance.

All forms and guidance in existence before 1 April 2012 that ERDF-supported projects have used or are currently using are available from your local programme delivery team.

Please ensure that you are using the correct forms and guidance for your project. If you have any questions, please contact the North West ERDF Programme Delivery Team on 0303 444 6520 or email nw.erdfenquiries@communities.gsi.gov.uk.

Details of the outputs that projects supported by the North West ERDF programme are required to deliver are set out in the document below.

ERDF North West: local indicator guidance

MS Word Document, 803 KB

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("ERDF North West: local indicator guidance").

ERDF North West: guide to the online carbon calculator

PDF, 27.9 KB, 3 pages

This file may not be accessible. Request a different format.

To request this document in an alternative format such as braille, audio or a different file type please email alternativeformats@communities.gsi.gov.uk quoting your address, telephone number along with the title of the publication ("ERDF North West: guide to the online carbon calculator").

Local management

In the North West, DCLG and its local delivery team is responsible for managing the ERDF programme, which is known as the Northwest Operational Programme (NWOP).

The local team allocates NWOP funding through a single appraisal process to different action areas within its 4 priority areas.

Local management committee

A local management committee has been formed to monitor, oversee and advise on the delivery of NWOP. The role and function of the local management committee is laid down by European Union legislation.

The local management committee is responsible for:

  • setting the direction for NWOP
  • driving NWOP forward
  • ensuring NWOP meets agreed objectives and targets
  • overseeing the strategic review of NWOP

The local management committee comprises senior representatives from across the region from:

  • DCLG
  • 4NW
  • sub-regional partnerships
  • local authorities
  • higher education
  • trade unions
  • the private and voluntary sectors

Local management sub-committees

The local management committee is assisted by 2 sub-committees:

  • the performance and monitoring sub-committee
  • the merseyside phasing-in sub-committee

The performance and monitoring sub-committee assists the local management committee in its duties in reviewing the programme in more detail.

The merseyside phasing-in sub-committee provides the local management committee with further resources and informed comments to focus on Merseyside during its transitional phasing in status.

Committee terms of reference and minutes

Terms of reference for all groups are available below as are minutes of recent meetings. Earlier minutes and past papers can be requested from the local team.
